name: Sisig
description: Sisig is a sizzling Kapampangan snack made from chopped pork face and liver with tangy calamansi and a kick of chili.
ingredients: 1/2 kg pork face and liver, finely chopped
instructions: Boil the pork until tender, then grill or fry until crispy.
Chop the meat finely and combine with diced onions and chilies.
Season with calamansi juice, soy sauce, salt, and pepper.
Mix in a little mayonnaise if desired, and serve hot on a sizzling plate.

name: Tocino
description: Tocino is a sweet and savory cured pork dish from Kapampangan cuisine—perfect for breakfast or as a main course.
instructions: Marinate the pork belly in brown sugar, soy sauce, garlic, and annatto powder for at least 4 hours.
Fry the pork in a pan until caramelized and cooked through.
Slice and serve with garlic fried rice and a fried egg.

name: Bringhe
description: Bringhe is a Kapampangan-style paella with glutinous rice, coconut milk, and shrimp, infused with the warm color of turmeric.
instructions: Sauté garlic in a little oil until fragrant.
Add shrimp and cook briefly until they turn pink.
Mix in the glutinous rice, coconut milk, turmeric, and bell pepper.
Season with salt and pepper and simmer gently until the rice is cooked and creamy.
Serve garnished with additional bell pepper if desired.

name: Pindang Damulag
description: Pindang Damulag is a savory dish featuring tender carabao meat simmered in vinegar and spices—a unique taste from Kapampangan culinary heritage.
ingredients: 1/2 kg carabao meat, cut into chunks
instructions: Boil the carabao meat until tender.
In a separate pan, sauté garlic and onion until soft.
Add the meat along with vinegar and bay leaf, and simmer for 10 minutes.
Adjust seasoning with salt and pepper and serve hot with steamed rice.

name: Kamaru
description: Kamaru is a traditional Kapampangan breakfast dish combining crab meat with raisins and eggs for a unique sweet and savory flavor.
instructions: Mix the crab meat with green peas, raisins, and beaten eggs.
Add vinegar and season with salt and pepper.
Sauté garlic briefly and fold into the mixture.
Steam or lightly fry until set, and serve warm.

name: Betute Tugak
description: Betute Tugak is a Kapampangan snack featuring tender pork belly layered with vegetables and a savory egg-liver mix.
instructions: Marinate pork belly with vinegar, salt, and pepper.
Mix liver spread with beaten eggs and water to create a binder.
Layer the pork slices with carrots and onions, then drizzle the egg mixture on top.
Steam the entire mixture until the pork is tender.
Serve hot as a savory snack.

name: Tidtad
description: Tidtad is a savory Kapampangan side dish that brings together shrimp, cheese, and a hint of sweetness from raisins.
instructions: Sauté chopped onions in a little oil until translucent.
Add the shrimp and cook until just done.
Stir in liver spread, raisins, and season with salt and pepper.
Mix in grated cheese and breadcrumbs, then simmer for a few minutes.
Serve as a flavorful side dish.

name: Morcon
description: Morcon is a festive Kapampangan meat roll filled with a savory mix of pork, vegetables, and raisins.
instructions: Mix ground pork with minced carrot, chopped onion, garlic, eggs, raisins, green peas, salt, and pepper.
Shape the mixture into a log and wrap tightly in foil.
Steam the log until cooked through, then slice into rounds.
Pan-fry the slices briefly to brown the exterior, and serve hot.

name: Embutido
description: Embutido is a classic Kapampangan meatloaf, combining pork belly, vegetables, raisins, and cheese for a delightful savory treat.
instructions: Mix all ingredients thoroughly.
Shape the mixture into a log and wrap with foil.
Steam the log for about 45 minutes until set.
Slice the embutido and pan-fry lightly for a crispy exterior before serving.

name: Lechon Kawali
description: Lechon Kawali is a popular Kapampangan dish featuring crispy-fried pork belly served with a tangy dipping sauce.
instructions: Boil the pork belly in salted water with garlic until tender.
Allow the meat to cool and then pat dry.
Deep-fry the pork belly until the skin is crispy and golden.
Cut into bite-sized pieces and serve with a dipping sauce of vinegar and garlic.

name: Kare-Kare
description: Kare-Kare is a rich and savory stew in Kapampangan cuisine made with oxtail, peanut sauce, and fresh vegetables.
instructions: Boil the oxtail or tripe until tender.
Dissolve peanut butter and annatto water into the broth, stirring well.
Add eggplant and bok choy, and simmer for a few more minutes.
Season with salt and add ground roasted rice for thickness if desired.
Serve hot with shrimp paste on the side.

name: Bopis
description: Bopis is a spicy and tangy Kapampangan dish featuring finely chopped pork offal sautéed with vinegar and spices.
ingredients: 1/2 kg pork lungs and heart, finely chopped
instructions: Sauté garlic and onions until soft.
Add the chopped offal and cook until well browned.
Stir in vinegar, chilies, salt, and pepper, and let simmer for 15 minutes.
Serve hot with steamed rice.

name: Dinuguan
description: Dinuguan is a traditional Filipino pork blood stew with a rich, savory, and tangy flavor, popular in Kapampangan cuisine.
ingredients: 1/2 kg pork meat and offal, diced
instructions: Sauté garlic and onion until fragrant.
Add pork and offal, and cook until lightly browned.
Pour in pork blood and vinegar, stirring continuously to avoid curdling.
Simmer until the sauce thickens and the flavors meld.
Season with salt and pepper, then serve hot with rice.

name: Paksiw na Lechon
description: Paksiw na Lechon is a savory Filipino dish where roasted lechon is simmered in vinegar with garlic and spices, offering a tangy twist on the classic roast.
ingredients: 1 whole roasted lechon, cut into pieces
instructions: In a pot, combine vinegar, garlic, onion, and bay leaf; bring to a simmer.
Add lechon pieces and let simmer for 15 minutes to absorb the flavors.
Adjust seasoning with salt and pepper, and serve hot with steamed rice.

name: Kalderetang Kambing
description: Kalderetang Kambing is a hearty goat stew in Kapampangan cuisine, simmered with vegetables in a rich tomato sauce.
ingredients: 1 kg goat meat, cut into chunks
instructions: Sauté garlic and onions in oil until soft.
Add goat meat and brown on all sides.
Pour in tomato sauce and enough water to cover the meat.
Add potatoes, carrots, and bell pepper; simmer until the meat is tender.
Season with salt and pepper, and serve hot with rice.

name: Chicharon Bulaklak
description: Chicharon Bulaklak is a crispy and savory Kapampangan snack made from deep-fried pork mesentery.
instructions: Clean and prepare the pork mesentery thoroughly.
Season with salt and pepper.
Deep-fry in hot oil until crispy and golden brown.
Drain on paper towels and serve with vinegar-based dipping sauce.

name: Menudo
description: Menudo is a classic Filipino stew in Kapampangan style, featuring tender pork with vegetables simmered in a savory tomato sauce.
ingredients: 1/2 kg pork, cut into small cubes
instructions: Sauté garlic and onion until translucent.
Add pork cubes and brown well.
Mix in tomato sauce, potatoes, carrots, and bell pepper.
Simmer until vegetables are tender and the meat is cooked.
Season with salt and pepper, then serve hot with rice.

name: Afritada
description: Afritada is a comforting chicken stew from Kapampangan cuisine, simmered in tomato sauce with vegetables.
instructions: Sauté garlic and onions in oil until soft.
Add chicken pieces and brown them lightly.
Stir in tomato sauce, potatoes, and carrots, then simmer until the chicken is tender.
Add bell peppers in the last 5 minutes and adjust seasoning.
Serve hot with steamed rice.

name: Adobong Puti
description: Adobong Puti is a lighter, tangier version of Filipino adobo that highlights vinegar and garlic without the soy sauce.
instructions: Sauté garlic in oil until fragrant.
Add chicken and lightly brown on all sides.
Pour in vinegar and add bay leaves.
Cover and simmer until the chicken is tender.
Adjust seasonings and serve hot with steamed rice.

name: Bulanglang
description: Bulanglang is a unique Kapampangan dish where tender chicken is combined with eggs, raisins, and cheese for a hearty flavor.
instructions: Season chicken slices with salt and pepper and lightly fry.
Mix in beaten eggs, garlic, carrots, and raisins.
Cook on low heat until the eggs are set and the flavors meld.
Stir in grated cheese just before serving, and serve hot.

name: Gatang Kuhol
description: Gatang Kuhol is a robust Kapampangan stew featuring carabao meat simmered with vegetables and eggs for a hearty meal.
instructions: Heat oil in a pan and sauté garlic and onions.
Add carabao meat and brown well.
Pour in water and bring to a boil.
Stir in beaten eggs, raisins, green peas, salt, and pepper.
Simmer until the meat is tender and the mixture is slightly thickened.
Serve hot with steamed rice.

name: Paksiw na Isda
description: Paksiw na Isda is a tangy and savory fish dish where tilapia is cooked in vinegar and aromatics, a Kapampangan favorite.
instructions: Arrange tilapia in a pan with tomatoes and onions.
Pour in water and vinegar, then add garlic, salt, and pepper.
Bring to a simmer and cook until the fish is tender and infused with flavors.
Serve hot with rice.

name: Arroz Valenciana
description: Arroz Valenciana is a creamy rice dish enriched with crab meat and coconut milk—a sumptuous main dish from Kapampangan cuisine.
instructions: Sauté garlic and onion in oil until soft.
Add crab meat and cook briefly.
Stir in glutinous rice and coconut milk; bring to a simmer.
Cook until the rice is soft and creamy.
Mix in breadcrumbs, adjust seasoning, and serve hot.

name: Kilayin
description: Kilayin is a tangy and savory Kapampangan breakfast dish made with diced chicken cooked in vinegar and garlic.
instructions: Heat oil in a pan and sauté garlic until aromatic.
Add chicken pieces and fry until lightly browned.
Pour in water and vinegar, add red chili if using.
Simmer until the chicken is tender and flavors meld.
Season with salt and pepper, and serve with rice.

name: Pork Asado
description: Pork Asado is a sweet and savory Kapampangan dish featuring marinated pork sirloin, perfectly caramelized and tender.
ingredients: 1/2 kg pork sirloin, cut into cubes
instructions: Marinate pork cubes in brown sugar, soy sauce, and garlic for 3–4 hours.
Heat a pan and sear the pork until caramelized.
Add water and simmer until tender.
Adjust seasoning as needed and serve with garlic fried rice.

name: Nilagang Baka
description: Nilagang Baka is a comforting Kapampangan beef stew simmered with vegetables, offering a warm and hearty flavor.
instructions: Boil beef shank with onions and garlic until tender.
Add potatoes and cabbage and simmer until cooked.
Season with salt and pepper, and serve hot with a side of rice.

name: Sinigang na Baboy
description: Sinigang na Baboy is a tangy and refreshing pork sour soup, a staple in Kapampangan homes.
ingredients: 1/2 kg pork belly, cut into pieces
Tamarind soup base or fresh tamarind
instructions: Boil pork belly with tomatoes and onions until tender.
Add tamarind base and radishes, and simmer for a few minutes.
Add kangkong and adjust salt.
Serve hot with steamed rice.

name: Ginisang Monggo
description: Ginisang Monggo is a hearty mung bean stew often enjoyed for breakfast, featuring savory aromatics and rich flavors.
instructions: Drain and boil the mung beans until soft.
In a pan, sauté garlic, onion, and tomato until tender.
Mix in the boiled mung beans and simmer for 10 minutes.
Season with salt and pepper, then serve with rice.

name: Tokwa't Baboy
description: Tokwa't Baboy is a classic Filipino dish combining tender pork with crispy tofu, dressed in a tangy garlic-vinegar sauce.
ingredients: 1/2 kg pork belly, boiled and sliced
instructions: Combine boiled pork belly and fried tofu in a bowl.
Mix in garlic and vinegar, and season with salt and pepper.
Top with chopped onions and serve as an appetizer or side dish.

name: Pritong Lumpia
description: Pritong Lumpia is a crispy Filipino spring roll filled with a savory mixture of pork and vegetables—a popular snack in Kapampangan cuisine.
instructions: Mix ground pork with carrots, cabbage, garlic, onion, salt, and pepper.
Place a spoonful of the mixture on a lumpia wrapper and roll tightly.
Deep-fry the lumpia until golden and crispy.
Drain on paper towels and serve with a dipping sauce.

name: Pancit Luglug
description: Pancit Luglug is a flavorful noodle dish in Kapampangan style, combining tender rice noodles with savory broth and a generous topping of cheese.
instructions: Boil the rice noodles until tender, then drain.
Warm the pork broth and mix with the noodles.
Top with grated cheese, sautéed onions, and sliced chili.
Season with salt and serve hot.

name: Pancit Palabok
description: Pancit Palabok is a festive Kapampangan noodle dish topped with seafood, chicharon, and a rich shrimp broth.
instructions: Boil the rice noodles until cooked, then set aside.
Warm the shrimp broth and mix in the flaked tilapia.
Arrange the noodles on a plate and pour the broth mixture over them.
Top with grated chicharon, boiled eggs, and crispy garlic.
Season with salt and pepper and serve.

name: Ginataang Langka
description: Ginataang Langka is a hearty Kapampangan dish made with tender pork belly and unripe jackfruit in a creamy coconut milk sauce.
ingredients: 1/2 kg pork belly, cut into cubes
1 small unripe jackfruit (langka), cut into strips
instructions: Sauté garlic and onion in oil until aromatic.
Add pork belly and cook until slightly browned.
Mix in jackfruit and pour in coconut milk.
Simmer until pork is tender and the flavors meld.
Season with salt and pepper and serve hot with rice.

name: Ginataang Puso ng Saging
description: Ginataang Puso ng Saging is a unique Kapampangan dish where tilapia is simmered with banana hearts in a rich, creamy coconut milk sauce.
ingredients: 1 cup banana hearts (puso ng saging), sliced
instructions: Sauté garlic and onion in a little oil.
Add tilapia and cook briefly.
Mix in banana hearts and coconut milk.
Simmer until the flavors meld and the sauce thickens slightly.
Season with salt and pepper and serve hot.

name: Laing
description: Laing is a classic Kapampangan dish featuring dried taro leaves simmered in rich coconut milk with a hint of shrimp paste, balancing spicy and savory flavors.
instructions: Rinse taro leaves thoroughly.
Sauté garlic, onion, and red chilies in a pot until fragrant.
Add taro leaves and stir-fry briefly.
Pour in coconut milk and simmer until the leaves are tender.
Stir in coconut cream and bagoong, adjust salt, and simmer for another 10 minutes.
Serve hot with steamed rice.

name: Ukoy
description: Ukoy is a crispy Filipino fritter made with shrimp and vegetables, a popular snack in Kapampangan cuisine.
instructions: Mix shrimp, bean sprouts, grated squash, and egg with rice flour until combined.
Season with salt and pepper.
Heat oil in a pan and drop spoonfuls of the mixture to form patties.
Fry until crispy and golden on both sides.
Drain on paper towels and serve with a vinegar dipping sauce.

name: Tortang Talong
description: Tortang Talong is a popular Filipino breakfast dish where grilled eggplant is dipped in egg and fried to perfection.
instructions: Grill the eggplants until the skin is charred and the flesh softens.
Peel the skin off carefully and flatten the eggplants.
Dip each eggplant in beaten eggs, season with salt and pepper.
Pan-fry until golden brown on both sides.
Serve hot with a side of tomatoes or rice.

name: Inihaw na Bangus
description: Inihaw na Bangus is a classic grilled milkfish from Kapampangan cuisine, marinated in garlic and calamansi for a fresh, tangy flavor.
instructions: Marinate the bangus with garlic, calamansi, salt, and pepper for at least 30 minutes.
Preheat the grill and brush the fish with oil.
Grill the bangus on both sides until fully cooked and slightly charred.
Serve hot with a side of rice and a dipping sauce.

name: Rellenong Bangus
description: Rellenong Bangus is a stuffed milkfish dish in Kapampangan cuisine, where the fish is filled with a savory vegetable and egg mixture.
ingredients: 1/2 cup vegetables (carrot and bell pepper), finely chopped
instructions: Flake the milkfish and combine with chopped vegetables, onion, egg, salt, and pepper.
Stuff the mixture back into the cleaned fish skin or form into patties.
Pan-fry until golden brown and crispy.
Serve hot with a dipping sauce and steamed rice.

name: Tinolang Manok
description: Tinolang Manok is a comforting chicken soup in Kapampangan cuisine, enriched with green papaya and leafy greens.
instructions: Sauté garlic and onion until translucent.
Add chicken and brown lightly.
Pour in water or broth and simmer until chicken is tender.
Add green papaya and cook until just soft.
Stir in chili leaves, season with salt and pepper, and simmer for another minute.
Serve hot with steamed rice.

name: Chicken Inasal
description: Chicken Inasal is a signature grilled chicken dish from Kapampangan cuisine, marinated in a tangy, garlicky mixture for vibrant flavor.
instructions: Marinate the chicken pieces in calamansi juice, soy sauce, garlic, annatto oil, salt, and pepper for at least 3 hours.
Grill the chicken over medium heat until cooked through and slightly charred.
Baste with extra marinade during grilling.
Serve hot with garlic rice and a side of pickled vegetables.

name: Pastel
description: Pastel is a Kapampangan version of a savory roll filled with shrimp and vegetables, steamed to perfection.
instructions: Mix shrimp, vegetables, egg, and soy sauce, and season with salt and pepper.
Place a portion of the mixture on a lumpia wrapper and roll tightly.
Steam the rolls for 20 minutes until set.
Slice and lightly pan-fry to crisp the edges, if desired.
Serve warm.

name: Pininyahang Manok
description: Pininyahang Manok features chicken simmered in a creamy coconut milk sauce with pineapple, blending sweet and savory Kapampangan flavors.
instructions: Sauté garlic until fragrant, then add chicken and brown slightly.
Pour in coconut milk and add pineapple and bell pepper.
Simmer until the chicken is tender and the sauce thickens.
Adjust seasonings and serve hot with rice.

name: Ginataang Manok
description: Ginataang Manok is a comforting chicken dish in Kapampangan style, simmered in coconut milk with a touch of sweetness from vegetables.
instructions: Sauté garlic and onion until softened.
Add chicken and cook until lightly browned.
Pour in coconut milk and add carrots.
Simmer until the chicken is cooked through and the sauce is creamy.
Season with salt and pepper and serve hot with rice.

name: Leche Flan
description: Leche Flan is a rich Filipino custard dessert with a silky texture and sweet caramel top, a true Kapampangan treat.
instructions: Melt sugar in a pan to create a golden caramel and pour into a flan mold.
Whisk egg yolks with condensed and evaporated milk.
Pour the custard mixture over the caramel in the mold.
Steam in a water bath for 30-40 minutes until set.
Chill before serving.

name: Brazo de Mercedes
description: Brazo de Mercedes is a delicate rolled dessert featuring a light meringue exterior filled with a rich, sweet egg yolk custard.
instructions: Beat egg whites with sugar to form a stiff meringue.
Spread the meringue thinly on a baking sheet and bake until firm.
Mix egg yolks with condensed milk and vanilla to create a custard filling.
Spread the filling on the meringue and roll tightly.
Chill before slicing and serving.

name: San Nicolas Cookies
description: San Nicolas Cookies are melt-in-your-mouth Filipino treats with a crisp edge and tender center, perfect as a dessert or snack.
instructions: Cream butter and sugar until light and fluffy.
Mix in the egg and vanilla extract.
Sift together flour, baking powder, and salt; combine with the butter mixture.
Shape dough into cookies and bake at 350°F for 12-15 minutes until lightly golden.
Cool and serve.

name: Turon
description: Turon is a beloved Filipino snack of caramelized bananas and jackfruit wrapped in a crispy spring roll wrapper.
instructions: Dust banana slices with brown sugar and wrap with a lumpia wrapper along with a few strips of jackfruit.
Deep-fry until crispy and golden.
Drain excess oil and serve warm.

name: Bibingka
description: Bibingka is a traditional Filipino rice cake with a soft, slightly chewy texture and subtle coconut flavor, often enjoyed as a dessert.
instructions: Mix rice flour, sugar, and baking powder together.
Stir in coconut milk and melted butter until smooth.
Pour the batter into a bowl lined with banana leaves.
Bake at 375°F for 25-30 minutes until set and slightly golden.
Serve warm with a dusting of sugar.

name: Puto Bumbong
description: Puto Bumbong is a traditional Filipino purple rice cake steamed in bamboo tubes, popular during festive occasions.
instructions: Soak the glutinous rice in water overnight.
Steam the rice in a bamboo tube or mold until soft.
Serve topped with grated coconut and a sprinkle of sugar.

name: Kutsinta
description: Kutsinta is a chewy Filipino steamed rice cake with a slightly gelatinous texture and a subtle sweetness, enjoyed with coconut.
instructions: Mix rice flour and lye water.
Dissolve brown sugar in water and combine with the flour mixture.
Pour into molds and steam for 25-30 minutes until set.
Serve topped with freshly grated coconut.

name: Sapin-Sapin
description: Sapin-Sapin is a vibrant Filipino layered rice cake with a sweet, chewy texture and a beautiful presentation.
instructions: Mix glutinous rice flour, coconut milk, and sugar to form a smooth batter.
Divide the batter into several portions and color each with different food colorings.
Layer the different colored batters in a greased pan.
Steam for 45-60 minutes until firm.
Cool, slice, and garnish with toasted coconut flakes.

name: Buko Pandan
description: Buko Pandan is a refreshing Filipino dessert featuring young coconut, pandan-flavored jelly, and a creamy, sweet dressing.
ingredients: 1 pack pandan jelly (prepared as per package instructions)
instructions: Mix shredded coconut with diced fruits.
Fold in the prepared pandan jelly cubes.
Add condensed milk and heavy cream, stirring until well combined.
Chill in the refrigerator for at least 2 hours before serving.

name: Halo-Halo
description: Halo-Halo is the ultimate Filipino dessert—a vibrant mix of sweet fruits, beans, milk, and ice, perfect for hot days.
ingredients: Assorted sweet beans and fruits (e.g., red mung beans, jackfruit, banana)
instructions: Layer the sweet beans and fruits at the bottom of a tall glass.
Fill the glass with crushed ice.
Drizzle evaporated milk over the ice.
Top with slices of leche flan and a scoop of ube ice cream.
Finish with a topping of shaved ice, if desired, and serve immediately.

name: Ube Halaya
description: Ube Halaya is a creamy and vibrantly colored Filipino dessert made from purple yam, steeped in the rich flavors of coconut and condensed milk.
instructions: Mash the boiled ube until smooth.
In a pan, melt butter and add the mashed ube.
Stir in coconut milk, condensed milk, and sugar.
Cook on low heat, stirring continuously until the mixture thickens.
Pour into a mold, cool, and serve as a rich purple yam dessert.

name: Maja Blanca
description: Maja Blanca is a smooth and creamy Filipino pudding made with coconut milk and corn, garnished with a sprinkle of cheese.
instructions: Mix coconut milk, corn, cornstarch, and sugar in a saucepan.
Cook over medium heat, stirring continuously until the mixture thickens and pulls away from the sides.
Pour into a greased dish and let cool.
Refrigerate for a few hours, then top with grated cheese before serving.

name: Palitaw
description: Palitaw is a traditional Filipino rice cake made from glutinous rice, dusted with sweet, grated coconut.
instructions: Soak glutinous rice in water overnight.
Shape the rice into small, flat cakes and steam until cooked.
Roll the cooked cakes in grated coconut mixed with sugar, then serve warm.

name: Cassava Cake
description: Cassava Cake is a dense, sweet Filipino dessert made from grated cassava and coconut milk, often enjoyed during celebrations.
instructions: Mix cassava, coconut milk, condensed milk, sugar, and butter in a bowl.
Pour the mixture into a greased baking pan.
Bake at 350°F for 45 minutes or until set and golden on top.
Sprinkle with grated cheese and serve warm.

name: Pichi-Pichi
description: Pichi-Pichi is a soft, chewy Filipino dessert made with grated cassava, often colored red and rolled in fresh coconut.
instructions: Mix grated cassava, sugar, and water in a pot and cook over medium heat until thickened.
If desired, add a few drops of red food coloring to give a vibrant hue.
Spoon the mixture into small molds and let cool to set.
Roll in grated coconut before serving.

name: Puto
description: Puto is a soft, steamed Filipino rice cake that is light and slightly sweet, perfect as a snack or side dish.
instructions: Mix rice flour, baking powder, sugar, egg, and water to form a smooth batter.
Pour into small molds and steam for 15-20 minutes until a toothpick inserted comes out clean.
Top with grated cheese if desired, and serve warm.

name: Suman
description: Suman is a traditional Filipino sticky rice cake wrapped in banana leaves, enjoyed as a snack or breakfast treat.
instructions: Mix glutinous rice with coconut milk and sugar.
Wrap portions of the mixture in banana leaves.
Steam the wrapped rice cakes for 30-40 minutes until fully cooked.
Serve warm with a drizzle of sugar or latik (coconut caramel).

name: Nilupak
description: Nilupak is a velvety Filipino dessert made from mashed cassava or saba, simmered with coconut milk and condensed milk.
instructions: Combine mashed cassava or saba with coconut milk, condensed milk, and sugar.
Cook over low heat while stirring until the mixture thickens.
Transfer to a greased pan, smooth the top, and let cool.
Cut into squares and serve as a rich, comforting dessert.

name: Ginataang Bilo-Bilo
description: Ginataang Bilo-Bilo is a comforting Filipino dessert featuring chewy rice balls and sweet potato in a creamy coconut milk broth.
instructions: Cook the sago pearls and set aside.
In a pot, combine coconut milk, sugar, diced sweet potato, and salt; bring to a simmer.
Add the glutinous rice balls and cooked sago; simmer until all ingredients are tender and the mixture slightly thickens.
Serve warm or chilled.

name: Banana Cue
description: Banana Cue is a popular Filipino street snack featuring caramelized saba bananas deep-fried to perfection.
instructions: Heat oil in a deep pan.
Roll each banana in brown sugar until evenly coated.
Deep-fry until the sugar caramelizes and the bananas are golden.
Drain excess oil on paper towels and serve warm on a stick.

name: Camote Cue
description: Camote Cue is a Filipino snack of sweet potatoes coated in caramelized brown sugar and deep-fried until crispy.
ingredients: 4 medium sweet potatoes (camote), peeled and cut into chunks
instructions: Heat oil in a deep pan.
Roll each sweet potato chunk in brown sugar until well coated.
Deep-fry until the sugar melts and forms a crisp, caramelized coating on the sweet potatoes.
Drain on paper towels and serve hot.
